borough: London Borough of Barking and Dagenham
decision_conditions: <p>The proposed development fails to comply with the requirements set out in Policy DMH5 of the draft Local Plan. Therefore, officers are unable to accept the principle of the proposed change of use. The application would result in a loss of generous family-size single dwellinghouse, which is a housing type in high demand within the Borough and of which local policies seek to preserve. The internal space of the dwelling also does not comply with the minimum requirements set out in the NDSS and London Plan to support a 5-bedroom HMO. The proposal also has the potential to increase activity level and coming and goings to and from the site as a result of unrelated individuals occupying the property, leading to additional levels of noise and disturbance that would impact the neighbours' amenity. Therefore, the negatives arising from the proposal are considered to outweigh any significant benefits as such having regard to the presumption in favour of sustainable development on balance. The principle of development is considered unacceptable and the proposed development should be refused.<br></p>

borough: London Borough of Barking and Dagenham
decision_conditions: <p><span style="font-size:11pt;">1.&nbsp;The proposed change of use from Class C3&nbsp;(residential) to Class E(f)&nbsp;Day Nursery would be a material change of use and therefore is considered to be development as defined by Section 55 of The Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended). The proposed day nursery would have very different characteristics from a residential dwelling in terms of its pattern of usage, likely parking demands, noise emissions, for this reason it is concluded that the proposal would have a material difference from the current residential use and as such would constitute development under s55. Additionally, there are no Permitted Development rights for a change of use from C3&nbsp;to E(f)&nbsp;and the application would therefore fail.&nbsp;</span><br></p>

<p><span style="font-size:11pt;">The development is within 2 metres of the boundary of the curtilage of the premises, as such fails to comply by A.1 (c(ii)).&nbsp;The proposed rear extension, therefore, fails to comply with Class A. 1(c(ii)), as such is found unlawful.</span><br></p>

decision_conditions: The proposed development fails to demonstrate that additional demand for parking from the development could be adequately accommodated in the surrounding area. The proposal is therefore likely to add unacceptably to parking stress and congestion in the vicinity of the application site.  As such, it fails to comply with the following policies which seek to ensure proposals show how car parking will be designed and managed and to take into consideration on-street parking availability and existing and planned public transport provision: National Planning Policy Framework (DLUHC, 2023) Policies T1 and T6.1 of the London Plan (March 2021) Policy BR9 of the Local Development Framework Borough Wide Development Plan Document (March 2011) Policy DMT2 of the London Borough of Barking and Dagenham’s Draft Local Plan: (Regulation 19 Submission Version, December 2021)

The proposed development would result in the loss of a family-sized dwellinghouse, the need for which is clearly demonstrated in the development plan and supporting evidence base. While it would provide a dwelling in the form of an HMO, it fails to demonstrate that this meets an identified need, and further would not provide an adequate quality of accommodation to support a high standard of living. As such, the proposal is considered to have a detrimental impact on the borough's housing supply and is contrary to the following policies: National Planning Policy Framework (DLUHC, 2023)Policy D6 of the London Plan (March 2021)Policies BC4 and BP6 of the Borough Wide DPD (March 2011)Policy CC1 of the Local Development Framework (LDF) Core Strategy (July 2010)Policies SP3 and DMH5 of the London Borough of Barking and Dagenham’s Draft Local Plan (December 2021)

borough: London Borough of Barking and Dagenham
decision_conditions:
The proposed development fails to demonstrate that additional demand for parking from the development could be adequately accommodated in the surrounding area. The proposal is therefore likely to add unacceptably to parking stress and congestion in the vicinity of the application site.  As such, it fails to comply with the following policies which seek to ensure proposals show how car parking will be designed and managed and to take into consideration on-street parking availability and existing and planned public transport provision:
 National Planning Policy Framework (NPPF) (DLUHC, 2023)
 Policies T1 and T6.1 of the London Plan (March 2021)
 Policy BR9 of the Local Development Framework Borough Wide
     Development Plan Document (March 2011)
 Policy DMT2 of The London Borough of Barking and Dagenham’s Draft
     Local Plan: (Regulation 19 Submission Version, December 2021)

 The proposed development, by reason of siting, design, mass and bulk, would disrupt the surrounding pattern of development as a discordant addition and would be at odds with the character of the surrounding dwellings. It therefore fails to represent a high quality design, and would have a detrimental impact on the character and appearance of the surrounding area, as well as to the local distinctiveness of the Becontree Estate, a non-designated heritage asset. The proposal thus fails to comply with the following policies which seek to ensure development proposals are sympathetic to local character and appearance and preserve or enhance the local distinctiveness and historic character:National Planning Policy Framework (NPPF) (DLUHC, 2023)
 Policies D4 and HC1 of the London Plan (March 2021)
 Policies CP2 and CP3 of
     the Local Development Framework Core Strategy (July 2010)
 Policy BP11 of the Local Development Framework Borough Wide
     Development Plan Document (March 2011)
 Policies SP2, DMD1 and DMD4 of The London Borough of Barking and Dagenham’s Draft
     Local Plan: (Regulation 19 Submission Version, December 2021)
subdivision_of_building: Proposal is on the land adjacent.
description: Construction of a new 1 x bed 2 person dwelling with associated external amenity area, parking, bicycle spaces and waste storage at land to side of 44 Rugby Gardens Dagenham RM9 4BA

borough: London Borough of Barking and Dagenham
decision_conditions: The proposed development is located in an area of poor public transport accessibility and fails to provide a suitable car parking strategy. In the absence of sufficient information, it has not been demonstrated that the proposal would not result in undue harm to parking stress in the area. As such, the proposal is found to be at odds with the following policies: National Planning Policy Framework (NPPF) (DLUHC, 2023) Policy T6 of the London Plan (March 2021)Policy BR9 of the Local Development Framework Borough Wide Development Plan Document (March 2011) Residential Extensions and Alterations Supplementary Planning Document (February 2012) Policy DMT 2 of the London Borough of Barking and Dagenham’s Draft Local Plan: (Regulation 19 Submission Version, December 2021)

The proposed development, by reason of scale, siting and design, would feature an incongruous roof form, would result in the closure of a characteristic gap at a prominent corner plot, would unbalance the semi-detached pair and would disrupt the surrounding pattern of development.  As such, the proposal would cause undue harm to the character and appearance of the host dwelling and surrounding area. The proposal is thus contrary to the following policies which seek to ensure that development recognises local character and promotes good design whilst protecting and enhancing historic environments: National Planning Policy Framework (NPPF) (DLUHC, July 2023) Policies D1 and D4 of the London Plan (March 2021) Policies CP2 and CP3 of the Local Development Framework (LDF) Core Strategy (July 2010)Policies BP2, BP8 and BP11 of the Local Development Framework (LDF) Borough Wide Development Plan Document (DPD) (March 2011) Residential Extensions and Alterations Supplementary Planning Document (February 2012) Policies SP 2 and DMD 1 of The London Borough of Barking and Dagenham’s Draft Local Plan: (Regulation 19 Submission Version, December 2021

decision_conditions:
<p>The internal use of the proposed first floor side extension would be a single person bedroom. The proposed bedroom would fail to comply with&nbsp;the minimum national internal space standards and it would&nbsp;be contrary&nbsp;to:<br></p><ul><li>Paragraph 10(c) in the Technical housing standards – nationally
described space standard (March 2015)<br></li><li>Part F(3) in Policy D6 of the London Plan (March 2021)</li></ul>

<p>The proposed first floor side extension by reason of its width and insufficient setback from the common shared boundary with Number 43&nbsp;Westrow Drive&nbsp;would be an incongruous and unsympathetic addition that would contribute to terracing effect by closing the gap and losing the openness between terrace groups. The development would cause harm to the character and appearance of the host dwelling and wider surrounding street scene and it would be contrary to:</p><ul><li>Paragraphs 131 and 135 of the National Planning Policy Framework (December 2023)</li><li>Policy D4 of the London Plan (March 2021)</li><li>Policy CP3&nbsp;of the Core Strategy (July 2010)</li><li>Policy BP11&nbsp;of the Borough Wide Development Plan Document (DPD) (March 2011)</li><li>Policies SP 2, DMD 1, and DMD 6 of the London Borough of Barking and Dagenham’s&nbsp;draft&nbsp;Local Plan 2037 (December 2021)</li><li>Paragraph 5.4.2(a) of the&nbsp;Council's&nbsp;Residential Extensions and Alterations&nbsp;Supplementary Planning Documents&nbsp;(February 2012)</li></ul>

decision_conditions:
The proposed development, by reason of siting, scale, design and massing, would imbalance the symmetry of the terrace and would be at odds with the character of the immediate surroundings. The extensions introduce a discordance to the terrace, and introduce a mass which will be particularly prominent from the front and side elevations of the dwelling. The combined extensions would would substantially close off the openness of the corner plot at both ground and first floor levels, restricting the long term views down Woodrush Way, and would also compromise the openness of the pavement and the entrance to the cul-de-sac. The proposal is therefore contrary to:

- National Planning Policy Framework National Planning Policy Framework (NPPF) (December, 2023)

- Policy D4 of the London Plan (March 2021)

- Policy CP3 of the Local Development Framework (LDF) Core Strategy (July 2010)

- Policies BP8 and BP11 of the Local Development Framework (LDF) Borough Wide Development Plan Document (DPD) (March 2011)

- The Residential Extensions and Alterations Supplementary Planning Document (February 2012)

- Policies SP2, DMD1 and DMD6 of The London Borough of Barking and Dagenham’s Draft Local Plan: (Regulation 19 Submission Version, December 2021)
description: Construction of a single storey front extension and a two storey side extension

Specifically the application fails to demonstrate the change of use would not be material and/or would not constitute "development", according to S55 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended).<br></p>

decision_conditions: <p>The proposal, by reason of bulk, mass, scale, siting and design, would be an undesirable addition which would not appear subservient to the original dwelling and would&nbsp;unbalance the symmetry and uniformity of the dwelling with the adjacent semi-detached twin. Further, it would close&nbsp;off the corner plot and bringing forward the building line at a prominent junction, posing potential harm on the highway.&nbsp; As such, it fails to respect or reflect the character of the original dwelling, the semi-detached pair of which it forms a part, and the surrounding area, causing harm to each of these as well as to the street scene along Croppath Road and Hunters Square , notably given the location of the application site within the Becontree Estate. As such, the proposed development is contrary to:</p><ul><li>Paragraphs 131, 135, 203, 209 of the National Planning Policy Framework &nbsp;(NPPF) (DLUHC, December 2023)<br></li><li>Policies&nbsp;D4 and HC1 of the London Plan (March 2021)</li><li>Policies CP2 and CP3 of the Local Development Framework (LDF) Core Strategy (July 2010)</li><li>Policies BP2, BP8 and BP11 of the Local Development Framework (LDF) Borough Wide Development Plan Document (DPD) (March 2011)</li><li>Policies SP2, DMD1, DMD4 and DMD6 of The London Borough of Barking and Dagenham’s Draft Local Plan: (Regulation 19 Submission Version, December 2021)</li><li>The Residential Extensions and Alterations Supplementary Planning Document (February 2012)</li></ul>
